focus_skills: Linear inequalities in one or two variables
Systems of 2 linear equations in 2 variables

questions.skill: Linear inequalities in one or two variables
questions.question: To be eligible for a scholarship, a student must have at least <math><mn>1200</mn></math> total points from two exams. The first exam is worth up to <math><mn>800</mn></math> points, and the second is worth up to <math><mn>600</mn></math> points. If a student scored <math><mn>750</mn></math> on the first exam, what is the minimum score needed on the second exam to be eligible?
questions.explanation: Let <math><mi>s</mi></math> be the score on the second exam. The total points must be at least <math><mn>1200</mn></math>. The inequality is <math><mn>750</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>≥</mo><mn>1200</mn></math>. Subtract <math><mn>750</mn></math> from both sides: <math><mi>s</mi><mo>≥</mo><mn>450</mn></math>. The minimum score needed is <math><mn>450</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Translate phrases like 'at least' into <math><mo>≥</mo></math> and 'minimum' into the smallest value satisfying the inequality.

questions.question: A right triangle has legs of length <math><mn>9</mn></math> and <math><mn>12</mn></math>. What is the length of the hypotenuse?
questions.explanation: Using the Pythagorean theorem: <math><msup><mi>c</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>9</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mn>12</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>81</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>144</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>225</mn></math>. Thus, <math><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo><msqrt><mn>225</mn></msqrt><mo>=</mo><mn>15</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Memorize common Pythagorean triples like (9, 12, 15) to save time on calculations.

questions.question: A store is having a sale where all items are <math><mn>30</mn><mo>%</mo></math> off. If the original price of a jacket is <math><mn>80</mn></math> dollars, what is the sale price?
questions.explanation: <math><mn>30</mn><mo>%</mo></math> of <math><mn>80</mn></math> is <math><mn>0.30</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>80</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>24</mn></math>. Subtract from original price: <math><mn>80</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>24</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>56</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For percent-off problems, calculate the discount first, then subtract from the original price.

questions.question: If <math><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>8</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Subtract <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi></math> from both sides: <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></math>. Add <math><mn>12</mn></math>: <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>20</mn></math>. Divide by <math><mn>2</mn></math>: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When solving linear equations, always perform the same operation on both sides to maintain equality.

questions.skill: Linear inequalities in one or two variables
questions.question: A shipping company charges a flat fee of <math><mn>15</mn></math> dollars plus <math><mn>2.50</mn></math> dollars per pound for packages up to <math><mn>20</mn></math> pounds. If a customer wants to spend at most <math><mn>60</mn></math> dollars, what is the maximum weight of the package they can ship?
questions.explanation: Let <math><mi>w</mi></math> be the weight in pounds. The cost is <math><mn>15</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>2.50</mn><mi>w</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>60</mn></math>. Subtract <math><mn>15</mn></math>: <math><mn>2.50</mn><mi>w</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>45</mn></math>. Divide by <math><mn>2.50</mn></math>: <math><mi>w</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>18</mn></math>. So the maximum weight is <math><mn>18</mn></math> pounds.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For word problems involving inequalities, define a variable, write the inequality, then solve step-by-step.

questions.skill: Ratios, rates, proportional relationships, and units
questions.question: A car travels <math><mn>240</mn></math> miles on <math><mn>8</mn></math> gallons of gas. At this rate, how many gallons are needed to travel <math><mn>360</mn></math> miles?
questions.explanation: Miles per gallon: <math><mn>240</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>30</mn></math> mpg. Gallons needed for <math><mn>360</mn></math> miles: <math><mn>360</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>30</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math> gallons.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Set up a proportion: <math><mfrac><mrow><mn>240</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>8</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>360</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac></math> and cross-multiply.

questions.question: Which of the following is equivalent to <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>9</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: The expression is a perfect square trinomial: <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Recognize common binomial squares: <math><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>a</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>a</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>.

questions.question: The length of a rectangle is three times its width. If the area is <math><mn>108</mn></math> square inches, what is the perimeter, in inches?
questions.explanation: Let width = <math><mi>w</mi></math>, length = <math><mn>3</mn><mi>w</mi></math>. Area = <math><mi>w</mi><mo>×</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>w</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><msup><mi>w</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>108</mn></math>. So <math><msup><mi>w</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>36</mn></math>, <math><mi>w</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>. Length = <math><mn>18</mn></math>. Perimeter = <math><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>18</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>48</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For rectangle problems, use <math><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>l</mi><mi>w</mi></math> and <math><mi>P</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>w</mi><mo>)</mo></math>.

questions.question: If <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>9</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>14</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, what is the sum of the solutions?
questions.explanation: Factor the quadratic: <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. Solutions are <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math> and <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></math>. Sum = <math><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For a quadratic <math><msup><mi>a</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, the sum of solutions is <math><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mi>b</mi><mi>a</mi></mfrac></math>.

questions.skill: One-variable data: distributions and measures of center and spread
questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg' style='font-family: Arial, sans-serif;'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><line x1='50' y1='40' x2='350' y2='40' stroke='#e0e0e0' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='50' y1='75' x2='350' y2='75' stroke='#e0e0e0' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='50' y1='110' x2='350' y2='110' stroke='#e0e0e0' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='50' y1='145' x2='350' y2='145' stroke='#e0e0e0' stroke-width='1'/><rect x='70' y='110' width='50' height='70' fill='#4A90E2' stroke='black'/><rect x='140' y='40' width='50' height='140' fill='#4A90E2' stroke='black'/><rect x='210' y='75' width='50' height='105' fill='#4A90E2' stroke='black'/><rect x='280' y='5' width='50' height='175' fill='#4A90E2' stroke='black'/><line x1='50' y1='180' x2='350' y2='180' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='95' y='200' font-size='14' text-anchor='middle'>A</text><text x='165' y='200' font-size='14' text-anchor='middle'>B</text><text x='235' y='200' font-size='14' text-anchor='middle'>C</text><text x='305' y='200' font-size='14' text-anchor='middle'>D</text><text x='40' y='180' font-size='12' text-anchor='end' dominant-baseline='middle'>0</text><text x='40' y='145' font-size='12' text-anchor='end' dominant-baseline='middle'>40</text><text x='40' y='110' font-size='12' text-anchor='end' dominant-baseline='middle'>80</text><text x='40' y='75' font-size='12' text-anchor='end' dominant-baseline='middle'>120</text><text x='40' y='40' font-size='12' text-anchor='end' dominant-baseline='middle'>160</text><text x='40' y='5' font-size='12' text-anchor='end' dominant-baseline='middle'>200</text><text x='200' y='240' font-size='14' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>Student</text><text x='15' y='100' font-size='14' text-anchor='middle' transform='rotate(-90 15,100)' font-weight='bold'>Score</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A bar graph displaying the test scores of four students. The x-axis represents the students labeled A, B, C, and D. The y-axis represents the Score. The heights of the bars are as follows: Student A is 80, Student B is 160, Student C is 120, and Student D is 200.
questions.question: The bar graph above shows the test scores of four students. Based on the data in the graph, what is the median of the scores?
questions.explanation:
To find the median, follow these steps:
1. Identify the value of each bar:
  • Student A: 80
  • Student B: 160
  • Student C: 120
  • Student D: 200
2. Order the data from least to greatest:
80, 120, 160, 200

3. Calculate the median:
Since there is an even number of data points (4), the median is the average of the two middle values (120 and 160).

Median=120+1602=2802=140
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg' style='font-family: Arial, sans-serif;'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><text x='200' y='15' font-size='16' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>Ordered Scores</text><rect x='50' y='110' width='60' height='70' fill='#e0e0e0' stroke='black'/><text x='80' y='105' text-anchor='middle'>80</text><rect x='130' y='75' width='60' height='105' fill='#ffcccc' stroke='red' stroke-width='2'/><text x='160' y='70' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>120</text><rect x='210' y='40' width='60' height='140' fill='#ffcccc' stroke='red' stroke-width='2'/><text x='240' y='35' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>160</text><rect x='290' y='5' width='60' height='175' fill='#e0e0e0' stroke='black'/><text x='320' y='25' text-anchor='middle'>200</text><line x1='30' y1='180' x2='370' y2='180' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><path d='M 160 190 Q 200 230 240 190' stroke='red' fill='transparent' stroke-dasharray='5,5'/><text x='200' y='240' fill='red' text-anchor='middle'>Average = 140</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: A chart showing the bars rearranged in ascending order of height: 80, 120, 160, 200. The two middle bars (120 and 160) are highlighted in red, indicating that the median is calculated by taking the average of these two values.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When calculating the median from a graph, do not just select the 'middle looking' bar. Always list the numeric values in ascending order first.

questions.skill: Systems of 2 linear equations in 2 variables
questions.question: If <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math> and <math><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Solve the system. From the second equation, <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn></math>. Substitute into the first: <math><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math> → <math><mn>6</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math> → <math><mn>7</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> → <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. Then <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>. So <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For systems of equations, elimination or substitution are reliable methods. Check for simple integer solutions first.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg' style='font-family: Arial, sans-serif;'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><defs><pattern id='grid' width='30' height='30' patternUnits='userSpaceOnUse'><path d='M 30 0 L 0 0 0 30' fill='none' stroke='#f0f0f0' stroke-width='1'/></pattern></defs><rect width='400' height='300' fill='url(#grid)'/><line x1='40' y1='260' x2='380' y2='260' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='40' y1='20' x2='40' y2='260' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><path d='M 40 260 Q 160 -100 280 260' stroke='#2c3e50' fill='none' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='160' y1='80' x2='160' y2='260' stroke='#7f8c8d' stroke-width='1' stroke-dasharray='4'/><circle cx='160' cy='80' r='4' fill='#e74c3c'/><circle cx='220' cy='125' r='4' fill='#3498db'/><text x='170' y='75' font-size='12' font-weight='bold'>Vertex (h, 12)</text><text x='230' y='125' font-size='12' font-weight='bold'>(3, 9)</text><text x='35' y='275' font-size='12'>0</text><text x='160' y='275' font-size='12'>h</text><text x='280' y='275' font-size='12'>2h</text><text x='390' y='260' font-size='12' font-weight='bold'>x</text><text x='40' y='15' font-size='12' font-weight='bold'>y</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A coordinate plane showing a downward-opening parabola starting at the origin (0,0). The vertex is labeled at (h, 12). The curve passes through a plotted point labeled (3, 9) and intersects the x-axis again at 2h.
questions.question: A parabola has zeros at <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>h</mi></math>. The vertex of the parabola is at <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>(</mo><mi>h</mi><mo>,</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. If the parabola passes through the point <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>)</mo></math> and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>h</mi><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></math>, what is the value of <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>h</mi></math>?
questions.explanation:
To solve for h, we can use the Vertex Form of a parabola, y=a(x-h)2+k, because we know the vertex is (h,12).



Step 1: Set up the equation.
Substitute the vertex k=12 into the equation:
y=a(x-h)2+12
Step 2: Use the known point (0,0).
Since the parabola has a zero at x=0, it passes through the origin. Substitute x=0 and y=0 to express a in terms of h:
0=a(0-h)2+12-12=ah2 ⇒ a=-12h2
Step 3: Use the second point (3,9).
Substitute x=3, y=9, and our expression for a into the vertex form:
9=-12h2(3-h)2+12
Simplify:
-3=-12(3-h)2h214=(3-h)2h2
Taking the square root of both sides:
12=3-hhh=2(3-h) ⇒ h=6-2h ⇒ 3h=6 ⇒ h=2
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg' style='font-family: Arial, sans-serif;'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><defs><pattern id='grid_exp' width='30' height='30' patternUnits='userSpaceOnUse'><path d='M 30 0 L 0 0 0 30' fill='none' stroke='#f0f0f0' stroke-width='1'/></pattern></defs><rect width='400' height='300' fill='url(#grid_exp)'/><line x1='40' y1='260' x2='380' y2='260' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='40' y1='20' x2='40' y2='260' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><path d='M 40 260 Q 160 -100 280 260' stroke='#2c3e50' fill='none' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='160' y1='80' x2='160' y2='260' stroke='#e74c3c' stroke-width='2' stroke-dasharray='4'/><circle cx='160' cy='80' r='5' fill='#e74c3c'/><circle cx='220' cy='125' r='5' fill='#3498db'/><text x='170' y='75' font-size='12' font-weight='bold' fill='#c0392b'>Vertex (2, 12)</text><text x='230' y='125' font-size='12' font-weight='bold' fill='#2980b9'>Point (3, 9)</text><text x='35' y='275' font-size='12'>0</text><text x='160' y='275' font-size='12' font-weight='bold' fill='#e74c3c'>h=2</text><text x='280' y='275' font-size='12'>2h=4</text><text x='390' y='260' font-size='12' font-weight='bold'>x</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The specific parabola graph for the solution h=2. The curve peaks at (2,12), passes through (3,9), and intersects the x-axis at 0 and 4.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When given the vertex (h, k), always start with vertex form: <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>h</mi><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>k</mi></math>. Use any other given points (like roots) to solve for the unknowns 'a' and 'h'.

questions.skill: Linear inequalities in one or two variables
questions.question: A company manufactures two types of chairs: standard and deluxe. Each standard chair requires <math><mn>2</mn></math> hours of labor and yields a profit of <math><mn>40</mn></math> dollars. Each deluxe chair requires <math><mn>3</mn></math> hours of labor and yields a profit of <math><mn>60</mn></math> dollars. If the company has at most <math><mn>120</mn></math> labor hours available and wants to maximize profit, which of the following systems of inequalities represents the constraints? Let <math><mi>s</mi></math> be number of standard chairs and <math><mi>d</mi></math> be number of deluxe chairs.
questions.explanation: The constraint is on labor hours: each standard uses <math><mn>2</mn></math> hours, each deluxe uses <math><mn>3</mn></math> hours, total hours must be at most <math><mn>120</mn></math>: <math><mn>2</mn><mi>s</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>d</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>120</mn></math>. Also, numbers of chairs cannot be negative: <math><mi>s</mi><mo>≥</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mi>d</mi><mo>≥</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. The profit function <math><mn>40</mn><mi>s</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>60</mn><mi>d</mi></math> is to be maximized, but is not part of constraints.
questions.score_improvement_tip: In optimization problems, constraints are usually inequalities limiting resources (time, materials). The objective function is what you maximize or minimize.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg' style='font-family: Arial, sans-serif;'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><defs><pattern id='grid14' width='40' height='40' patternUnits='userSpaceOnUse'><path d='M 40 0 L 0 0 0 40' fill='none' stroke='#f0f0f0' stroke-width='1'/></pattern></defs><rect x='50' stroke-width='2'/><circle cx='90' cy='130' r='4' fill='#2c3e50'/><circle cx='130' cy='130' r='4' fill='#2c3e50'/><circle cx='170' cy='122' r='4' fill='#2c3e50'/><circle cx='210' cy='130' r='4' fill='#2c3e50'/><circle cx='250' cy='138' r='4' fill='#2c3e50'/><circle cx='290' cy='130' r='4' fill='#2c3e50'/><circle cx='330' cy='122' r='4' fill='#2c3e50'/><text x='50' y='270' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>0</text><text x='90' y='270' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>1</text><text x='130' y='270' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>2</text><text x='170' y='270' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>3</text><text x='210' y='270' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>4</text><text x='250' y='270' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>5</text><text x='290' y='270' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>6</text><text x='330' y='270' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>7</text><text x='360' y='255' font-size='14' font-weight='bold'>x</text><text x='40' y='55' font-size='12' text-anchor='end' dominant-baseline='middle'>25</text><text x='40' y='95' font-size='12' text-anchor='end' dominant-baseline='middle'>20</text><text x='40' y='130' font-size='12' text-anchor='end' dominant-baseline='middle'>15</text><text x='40' y='170' font-size='12' text-anchor='end' dominant-baseline='middle'>10</text><text x='40' y='210' font-size='12' text-anchor='end' dominant-baseline='middle'>5</text><text x='40' y='250' font-size='12' text-anchor='end' dominant-baseline='middle'>0</text><text x='30' y='40' font-size='14' font-weight='bold'>y</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A scatterplot on a coordinate plane. The x-axis ranges from 0 to 7. The y-axis ranges from 0 to 25. There are 7 data points scattered horizontally, clustering closely around the y-value of 15.
questions.question: The scatterplot above shows the relationship between <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi></math> and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>y</mi></math>. A line of best fit for the data passes through the points <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>15</mn><mo>)</mo></math> and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>(</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>15</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. What is the slope of this line?
questions.explanation:
To find the slope of the line of best fit, we use the slope formula with the two given points: (x1,y1)=(2,15) and (x2,y2)=(6,15).

m=y2-y1x2-x1
Substitute the values:
m=15-156-2=04=0



Because the y-values are identical (y=15 for both points), there is no 'rise,' resulting in a horizontal line with a slope of 0.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg' style='font-family: Arial, sans-serif;'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><defs><pattern id='grid_exp14' width='40' height='40' patternUnits='userSpaceOnUse'><path d='M 40 0 L 0 0 0 40' fill='none' stroke='#f0f0f0' stroke-width='1'/></pattern></defs><rect x='50' y='50' width='300' height='200' fill='url(#grid_exp14)'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='50' y2='50' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='350' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><circle cx='90' cy='130' r='4' fill='#bdc3c7'/><circle cx='130' cy='130' r='4' fill='#bdc3c7'/><circle cx='170' cy='122' r='4' fill='#bdc3c7'/><circle cx='210' cy='130' r='4' fill='#bdc3c7'/><circle cx='250' cy='138' r='4' fill='#bdc3c7'/><circle cx='290' cy='130' r='4' fill='#bdc3c7'/><circle cx='330' cy='122' r='4' fill='#bdc3c7'/><line x1='50' y1='130' x2='350' y2='130' stroke='#e74c3c' stroke-width='3'/><circle cx='130' cy='130' r='6' fill='#e74c3c'/><circle cx='290' cy='130' r='6' fill='#e74c3c'/><text x='130' y='115' font-size='12' font-weight='bold' fill='#c0392b' text-anchor='middle'>(2, 15)</text><text x='290' y='115' font-size='12' font-weight='bold' fill='#c0392b' text-anchor='middle'>(6, 15)</text><text x='50' y='270' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>0</text><text x='330' y='270' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>7</text><text x='360' y='255' font-size='14' font-weight='bold'>x</text><text x='40' y='130' font-size='12' text-anchor='end' dominant-baseline='middle' font-weight='bold' fill='#c0392b'>15</text><text x='40' y='250' font-size='12' text-anchor='end' dominant-baseline='middle'>0</text><text x='30' y='40' font-size='14' font-weight='bold'>y</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The same scatterplot with a bold red horizontal line passing through y=15. The two specific points mentioned in the question, (2,15) and (6,15), are highlighted with large red dots, demonstrating that the line connecting them is perfectly flat.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Remember: 'Rise over Run'. If the line is flat, the Rise is 0, so the slope is 0. If the line is vertical, the Run is 0, so the slope is undefined.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg' style='font-family: Arial, sans-serif;'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><path d='M 80 220 L 360 220 L 200 40 Z' fill='#f9f9f9' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='200' y1='40' x2='200' y2='220' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' stroke-dasharray='4'/><rect x='200' y='210' width='10' height='10' fill='none' stroke='black'/><text x='70' y='235' font-size='14' font-weight='bold'>A</text><text x='370' y='235' font-size='14' font-weight='bold'>B</text><text x='200' y='30' font-size='14' font-weight='bold'>C</text><text x='205' y='235' font-size='14' font-weight='bold'>D</text><text x='190' y='140' font-size='14' text-anchor='end' font-style='italic'>h</text><text x='140' y='215' font-size='14' text-anchor='middle'>6</text><text x='280' y='215' font-size='14' text-anchor='middle'>8</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Triangle ABC with a horizontal base AB. An altitude, labeled 'h', drops from vertex C to point D on the base, forming a right angle. The base is split into two segments: the length of AD is 6 and the length of DB is 8.
questions.question: In triangle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math> above, altitude <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>C</mi><mi>D</mi></math> is drawn to base <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi></math>. If <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>D</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>D</mi><mi>B</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></math>, and the area of triangle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math> is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>84</mn></math>, what is the length of altitude <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>C</mi><mi>D</mi></math>?
questions.explanation:
To find the height, we use the formula for the area of a triangle: Area=12×base×height.



Step 1: Calculate the total base length (AB).
The base AB is composed of segments AD and DB.
Base=6+8=14
Step 2: Substitute known values into the area formula.
We know Area = 84 and Base = 14.
84=12×14×h
Step 3: Solve for h.
84=7hh=847=12
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg' style='font-family: Arial, sans-serif;'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><path d='M 80 220 L 360 220 L 200 40 Z' fill='#f0f0f0' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='200' y1='40' x2='200' y2='220' stroke='red' stroke-width='3'/><rect x='200' y='210' width='10' height='10' fill='none' stroke='black'/><text x='190' y='140' font-size='14' text-anchor='end' font-weight='bold' fill='red'>h=12</text><text x='140' y='215' font-size='14' text-anchor='middle'>6</text><text x='280' y='215' font-size='14' text-anchor='middle'>8</text><path d='M 80 245 L 80 255 L 360 255 L 360 245' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><text x='220' y='275' font-size='14' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>Total Base = 14</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The triangle with the calculated values filled in. The total base is labeled as 14 (6 + 8), and the altitude (height) is highlighted in red and labeled as h=12.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Always check if the 'base' is given as a single number or split into parts. If split, add them up before using the area formula: <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>Base</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>Part</mi><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>Part</mi><mn>2</mn></math>.

questions.question: Which expression is equivalent to <math><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfrac></math> for all <math><mi>x</mi><mo>≠</mo><mn>2</mn></math> and <math><mi>x</mi><mo>≠</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: Factor numerator and denominator: Numerator: <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></math>. Denominator: <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>=</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. So the expression becomes <math><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac></math>, for <math><mi>x</mi><mo>≠</mo><mn>2</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Simplify rational expressions by factoring both numerator and denominator, then canceling common factors, noting restrictions.

questions.question: A bag contains <math><mn>5</mn></math> red marbles, <math><mn>3</mn></math> blue marbles, and <math><mn>2</mn></math> green marbles. Two marbles are drawn at random without replacement. What is the probability that both marbles are red? Express your answer as a fraction.
questions.explanation: Total marbles = <math><mn>10</mn></math>. Probability first is red = <math><mfrac><mn>5</mn><mn>10</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math>. After drawing one red, remaining: <math><mn>4</mn></math> red, <math><mn>9</mn></math> total. Probability second is red = <math><mfrac><mn>4</mn><mn>9</mn></mfrac></math>. Multiply: <math><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mfrac><mn>4</mn><mn>9</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>4</mn><mn>18</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>9</mn></mfrac></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For 'without replacement' probability, multiply probabilities of each event, adjusting the total and favorable counts after each draw.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg' style='font-family: Arial, sans-serif;'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><circle cx='200' cy='150' r='100' fill='white' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><path d='M 200 150 L 300 150' stroke='black' stroke-width='1' stroke-dasharray='5,5'/><path d='M 200 150 L 250 63.4' stroke='black' stroke-width='1' stroke-dasharray='5,5'/><line x1='250' y1='63.4' x2='300' y2='150' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><circle cx='200' cy='150' r='3' fill='black'/><text x='310' y='155' font-size='14' font-weight='bold'>B</text><text x='250' y='55' font-size='14' font-weight='bold'>A</text><text x='185' y='155' font-size='14' font-weight='bold'>O</text><text x='290' y='100' font-size='14' font-weight='bold'>12</text><text x='225' y='145' font-size='12'>60°</text><path d='M 230 150 A 30 30 0 0 0 240 130' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A circle with center O. Points A and B lie on the circle. A chord connects points A and B, and its length is labeled as 12. Dashed lines represent the radii OA and OB. The central angle AOB is labeled as 60 degrees.
questions.question: In the circle above with center <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>O</mi></math>, the length of chord <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi></math> is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>12</mn></math> and the central angle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>∠</mo><mi>A</mi><mi>O</mi><mi>B</mi></math> is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msup><mn>60</mn><mo>°</mo></msup></math>. What is the length of arc <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi></math>?
questions.explanation:
To find the arc length, we must first determine the radius of the circle using the properties of the triangle formed by the chord and radii.



Step 1: Determine the radius (r).
In ΔAOB, radii OA and OB are equal, making the triangle isosceles. Since the vertex angle is 60°, the base angles must also be 60°. Therefore, ΔAOB is equilateral.
If the chord AB=12, then radius r=12.

Step 2: Calculate Arc Length.
Use the arc length formula with r=12 and θ=60°:
Arc=θ360×2πrArc=60360×2π(12)Arc=16×24π=4π
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg' style='font-family: Arial, sans-serif;'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><circle cx='200' cy='150' r='100' fill='none' stroke='#bdc3c7' stroke-width='1'/><polygon points='200,150 300,150 250,63.4' fill='#eaf2f8' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><text x='240' y='140' font-size='12' fill='#2c3e50'>60°</text><text x='270' y='90' font-size='12' fill='#2c3e50'>60°</text><text x='210' y='120' font-size='12' fill='#2c3e50'>60°</text><line x1='200' y1='150' x2='300' y2='150' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='200' y1='150' x2='250' y2='63.4' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><path d='M 300 150 A 100 100 0 0 0 250 63.4' fill='none' stroke='#e74c3c' stroke-width='4'/><text x='220' y='110' font-size='12' font-weight='bold' fill='#2980b9'>r = 12</text><text x='250' y='165' font-size='12' font-weight='bold' fill='#2980b9'>r = 12</text><text x='290' y='100' font-size='12' font-weight='bold'>Chord = 12</text><text x='310' y='110' font-size='14' font-weight='bold' fill='#e74c3c'>Arc = 4π</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The diagram highlights that Triangle AOB is equilateral (all angles 60 degrees). This proves that the radii (sides OA and OB) equal the chord length of 12. The arc AB is highlighted in red with the final calculation shown.
questions.score_improvement_tip: If a central angle is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msup><mn>60</mn><mo>°</mo></msup></math>, the triangle formed by the radii and the chord is Equilateral. This implies <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>Radius</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>Chord Length</mi></math>.

questions.skill: Linear inequalities in one or two variables
questions.question: If <math><mi>y</mi><mo>≥</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn></math> and <math><mi>y</mi><mo>≤</mo><mo>−</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn></math>, and <math><mi>x</mi></math> and <math><mi>y</mi></math> are integers, what is the maximum possible value of <math><mi>y</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: We have the system: <math><mi>y</mi><mo>≥</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn></math> and <math><mi>y</mi><mo>≤</mo><mo>−</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn></math>. The region is bounded above by the line <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn></math>. To maximize <math><mi>y</mi></math>, we want the largest <math><mi>y</mi></math> on that line that also satisfies <math><mi>y</mi><mo>≥</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn></math>. The line <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn></math> decreases as <math><mi>x</mi></math> increases, so the maximum <math><mi>y</mi></math> occurs at the smallest <math><mi>x</mi></math> that still satisfies the inequality. At <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math> satisfies both: <math><mn>10</mn><mo>≥</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn></math> and <math><mn>10</mn><mo>≤</mo><mn>10</mn></math>. No larger <math><mi>y</mi></math> is possible because <math><mi>y</mi></math> cannot exceed <math><mo>−</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn></math> and at <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> that gives <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math>. Thus the maximum integer <math><mi>y</mi></math> is 10.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Graph the inequalities to visualize the feasible region. The maximum y occurs at the highest point of the region, often at an intersection of boundary lines.

questions.question: If <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>17</mn></math> and <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>y</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Solve the system: From second equation, <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>9</mn></math>. Substitute into first: <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>17</mn></math> → <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>18</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>17</mn></math> → <math><mn>7</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>35</mn></math> → <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>. Then <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math>. So <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Solve linear systems by substitution or elimination. Once you find x and y, compute the required expression carefully.
